reasoning_trace.value: The paper includes several figures and tables. Figure 1 illustrates the concept of photonic-based THz ISAC for fiber-wireless networks and the principle of full-photonic THz ISAC signal generation, direct LFM reception, and de-chirping. Figure 2 shows the experimental setup of the photonic-based D-band THz ISAC system. Figure 3 presents the true-to-false target power ratio (TFTPR) of the signal from the BPD. Figure 4 displays the spectrums after FFT operation with TFLN-MZM operating at different bias points. Figure 5 shows the tested S11 and S21 parameters of the TFLN-MZM. Figure 6 presents the optical spectrums at different points in the system. Figure 7 shows the sensing SNR with different carrier frequencies and Vpp. Figure 8 presents the range resolution and sensing SNR with varying fiber lengths. Figure 9 illustrates the range profiles for the target at different distances and the measured distances before calibration. Figure 10 displays the BER with different center frequencies, Vpp, and baud rates.

reasoning_trace.description: Explain the System Mechanism and ISAC Coupling Mode found.
reasoning_trace.value: The system uses a photonic-based THz ISAC architecture, where communication and radar sensing functions are achieved through time-division multiplexing (TDM) of 16-QAM and LFM signals. The LFM signal is used for radar sensing, while the 16-QAM signal is used for communication. The system employs a thin-film lithium niobate Mach-Zehnder modulator (TFLN-MZM) for direct reception and de-chirping of the THz LFM echo signal. The TFLN-MZM operates at the minimum transmission point (MITP) to avoid false targets. The system also uses a balanced photodetector (BPD) for coherent homodyne detection of the de-chirped signal.

reasoning_trace.description: Validate the physical consistency of reported metrics (Rate/Resolution).
reasoning_trace.value: The system achieves a range resolution of 6 mm and a peak data rate of 116 Gbit/s at a center frequency of 134 GHz. The calibrated mean ranging error is less than 3 mm. The system's performance is consistent with the theoretical expectations, considering the limitations of the device bandwidth and the impact of fiber transmission on radar performance.

reasoning_trace.description: Identify the solved problems and remaining open challenges.
reasoning_trace.value: The system solves the problem of direct reception and de-chirping of THz LFM echo signals using a photonic-based approach. However, the system still faces challenges such as the impact of fiber transmission on radar performance, the need for high-bandwidth devices, and the potential for false targets. Future research directions include exploring the potential for deep fusion of ISAC waveforms, adopting joint geometric and probabilistic shaping, and improving the system's performance and robustness.
